It's honestly like fine dining status, but a fraction of the cost and again, the service is sooooo nice and friendly. I hope they continue to serve us their amazing food for decades to come! Wow just wow. This place was perfect.

My boyfriend and I arrived at this place 9ish. So the place was not busy whatsoever. When we arrived we were quickly greeted and sat down.

Food: I ordered the Chapati and Bengan Bharta. The Bengan bharta was not vegan so I asked the server if he could make it vegan and he said yes. When I got my food, I was extremely excited to try it because it looked so delicious! I first tried it with my chapati bread and it was so delicious. I definitely loved the spices with the eggplant. The flavor was so exceptional! I also tried it with brown rice and again amazed because it genuinely tasted that good to me. I'm definitely glad I ordered the Benga Bertha! 
My boyfriend ordered brown rice, fish tikka masala, and naan. He said his fish tikka masala was delicious. Overall, we really enjoyed our food. It was definitely a 5/5 for me!  

Service: From the beginning and end of our meal the service was spot on. Everyone was so helpful and kind. Especially when I asked for my dishes to be veganised. The servers were extremely spot on with the timing on asking us if we needed anything. It's such a small aspect but I really enjoy when they wait for all the food to be cooked and then serving it to us. Such a great experience with customer service!

The atmosphere of the place was quite relaxing! The decor and the look of the place was pleasing. Additionally, the whole restaurant is really clean!

I definitely recommend this place because the food is just very delicious, the place is clean, and the customer service is spot on. It's quite difficult to impress me but this place definitely did :)

naan.author: Ed U.
naan.review:
You probably know already that the Mission is home to a number of appetizing Indian eateries that run the gamut from modern street cart to more traditional fare. Places like Deccan Spice (review: http://bit.ly/2IvTrj2), Ritu (formerly DUM) Indian Soul Food (review: http://bit.ly/2Mx1i1Z), and Aslam's Rasoi (review: http://bit.ly/2tAeImW) impress with their diverse executions and tasty results. I came here for a quiet lunch after perusing appliances at Cherin's nearby and honestly didn't think Lotus SF was quite in the memorable category.

They have all the expected dishes on their menu - curries, biriyani, naans, tandoori - and they offer lunch specials worthy of attention. I decided to go for the reasonably priced $11.95 Tandoori Chicken Lunch Special  because it was dark meat only, definitely my preference. It certainly came with a lot of extras which in heftier days would have been a plus but now just seemed more like a carbalooza. First came a basket of naan that was enough for a family of four, none of whom could afford to be anorexic (photo: http://bit.ly/2yMAXv9).

Then came the tandoori chicken leg and thigh, a medium-size portion though a bit over cooked as it lay sitting on a bed of sautéed white onions (photo: http://bit.ly/2tBGtLT). This came with a cup of dal (photo: http://bit.ly/2KqiRnf). But wait, there was more. On another plate were a salad, a big helping of basmati rice, and a huge samosa, very crusty from its bath in the fryer (photo: http://bit.ly/2N4hw3K). It was a lot of food, and if you're looking for by-the-numbers execution, this place was as good as any. But portion didn't rule out everything else for me as I felt mixed on the results.

FOOD - 3 stars...lots to eat at lunch but it was light on poultry and way heavy on carbs
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...the decor was quite nice in a traditional way
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...very quiet and efficient and a lot of guys on staff at once
TOTAL - 3 stars...middle-of-the-road Indian food in a 'hood with a whole lotta strong South Asian choices

naan.author: Sabina S.
naan.review:
Lotus is a solid new Indian restaurant addition to the Mission food scene! The best part about this restaurant is their attention to the different diet restrictions that people have and attention to where they source ingredients from. Everything here is organic and everything can be made vegan or gluten-free, which I find awesome even though I myself don't have these restrictions. The decor is warm and inviting, the food is nourishing and tasty, and service is friendly and attentive!

We ordered the chicken tikka masala ($13.95), lamb seekh kebab ($17.95) and garlic naan ($3.95). The chicken tikka masala was delicious! I loved that the sauce wasn't as creamy as at other restaurants and therefore tasted more like home-cooked Indian food. I just wish they gave a few more chicken pieces given the price you are paying. 
The lamb kebabs were the absolute WINNER though. The meat was SO flavorful and perfectly cooked and came on a platter with yummy roasted onions and bell peppers. It was finger lickin good and I'd highly recommend this dish. Easily best kebab I've had. 
Garlic naan was also fantastic. It was the right level of thickness and crispness. 

I really enjoyed Lotus SF and can't wait to come back and try a few more dishes :).

First off, the naan here is insanely good. They have so many different flavors of naan we ordered three because we couldn't decide haha. Indian popped up as a top cuisine so I thought a quick walk to the Naan & Curry on 3rd & King would work. Then, I came across Lotus SF. Lots of stars and rave reviews. 

Hopped in the car and headed towards the Mission at 8:30pm on a Thursday. Normally, parking is tough to find based on the time and day of week, but was plentiful and to our surprise. 

The exterior is clean with big windows showing you these beautiful upholstered chairs and tables ready for you inside. Such a welcome relief from all the sad (in my opinion), yuppy, cookie-cutter restaurants with their drab, gray, box-y, cyber-y, minimalist decor. You won't find that here! Yes, this is a beautifully decorated place full of bright, happy colors that open your mind up and expand your mental and emotional horizons. The space used to belong to a tile company, so the whole floor is filled with colored tiles - it's so beautiful! All the art work comes from India and our waiter graciously explained all the different meanings and personalities contained in the works. It was really fascinating in itself!

Then comes the food. It could not have been more perfect. First, for those who are gluten-free or have food allergies, you won't find a more welcoming menu. They have the option of gluten-free naan! When's the last time you were able to find *that*?! And they print right on their menu that they care about your health and are glad to make you any dish to order, including something that is your favorite Indian dish that you don't see on the menu! I was wildly excited to get to eat the vegetable pakoras appetizer because, being gluten-free, I don't get to indulge in fried food very often. Our waiter also was careful to make all our dishes to our specifications, asking for us to tell him not just 'mild, medium or spicy' but, "on a scale of 1-10, is 'medium' a 5 for you or is it a 7?" We had the coconut chicken dish and the tikka masala (Yum! That was my favorite!) and they even offer brown rice for those who are more health conscious. Their vegetables are pesticide-free - they make a point of telling you that. It was very delicious, healthy food! You can't go wrong here.

But the most stellar, striking thing of all was the level of service we got. Amit was our server and he just had everything down perfectly! He had the perfect timing of knowing when to come refill our tea cups with yummy Masala chai and when to leave us alone to be engaged in deep conversation. And so I say, "Three cheers for this new neighborhood restaurant!" They are open for lunch Tuesday - Sunday which is a plus since there aren't too many healthy, affordable lunch options around here. And yes, I forgot to mention that it is a restaurant that you can still eat at if you're not a millionaire. Very exciting for people like me. And, again, that decor! First time out, I had an extremely generous portion of the magnificent dal makhni (requesting 'medium spicy'), which came with sides of white basmati rice (every grain perfect) garnished with saffron and peas, a salad of field greens (if you want dressing, ask), a lovely, big, fat samosa (potato & peas), and a basket of exceptionally fresh, fragrant and tasty naan (they offer a variety of breads & flavors and gluten-free naan, too). I took home leftovers in the box they so graciously provided, as even I couldn't eat so much food in one sitting.
ALL THIS for $12 (plus a generous tip, which they so richly deserve)!
Of course, there were other vegetarian options at that price (next time, I'll try the chana masala) as well as meat dishes (chicken, lamb) and fish & seafood (for about $1 to $4 more). I did not explore desserts (but will try the gulab jamon). This is the real deal in Northern Indian cuisine and ambience. (I bet that was the owner I saw standing by.) I can hardly wait to go back for more!

THIS IS THE REAL DEAL.
Greeting the customer with what looks like marble Ganeshas outside and big, brass ones inside, LOTUS SF continues with the theme of high quality and fine Indian art, from the fine paintings (including masterpieces of the Persian-influenced era) and a unique 3-D wood portrait (suggestive of the style of Yaacov Agam) of Indian Independence hero Kartar Singh Sarabha, to the fantastic floors (dramatic and sweeping marble-inlaid designs in bright blues, golds, and a variety of other colors and patterns--different for each section of the restaurant, and gorgeous faux-wood tile flooring in the bathrooms, which sparkle with cleanliness and chrome fixtures, and white-on-white, fine-geometric-patterned, fresco-like tile walls). 
And then there's lunch, all served on cloth tablecloths in beautiful, intricately patterned white-on-white china (made in Thailand) by charming staff from India and/or Nepal--while authentic Indian classical music plays in the background.
First time out, I had an extremely generous portion of the magnificent dal makhni (requesting 'medium spicy'), which came with sides of white basmati rice (every grain perfect) garnished with saffron and peas, a salad of field greens (if you want dressing, ask), a lovely, big, fat samosa (potato & peas), and a basket of exceptionally fresh, fragrant and tasty naan (they offer a variety of breads & flavors and gluten-free naan, too). I nearly broke out in Hallelujahs when I discovered that they did NOT sweeten their chai. I took home leftovers in the box they so graciously provided, as even I couldn't eat so much food in one sitting.
ALL THIS for $12 (plus a generous tip, which they so richly deserve)!
Of course, there were other vegetarian options at that price (next time, I'll try the chana masala) as well as meat dishes (chicken, lamb) and fish & seafood (for about $1 to $4 more). I did not explore desserts (but will try the gulab jamon). This is the real deal in Northern Indian cuisine and ambience. (I bet that was the owner I saw standing by.) I can hardly wait to go back for more!

My BF was feeling a bit under the weather and we just did a full week of going vegetarian, so I perused for the best "Vegetarian " near me. Indian popped up as a top cuisine so I thought a quick walk to the Naan & Curry on 3rd & King would work. Then, I came across Lotus SF. Lots of stars and rave reviews. 

Hopped in the car and headed towards the Mission at 8:30pm on a Thursday. Normally, parking is tough to find based on the time and day of week, but was plentiful and to our surprise. 

The exterior is clean with big windows showing you these beautiful upholstered chairs and tables ready for you inside. A white stone elephant greets you next to the front door, as does a smiling server upon entry. We were surprised, and for a quiet night, we chose a window seat and was equally thrilled at seeing the deliciousness inside their menu.

We chose garlic naan, basmati rice, palak paneer and a organic chicken coconut curry (extra $1.50 for organic chicken), a cup of mango lassi and Sonoma Zinfandel. We were NOT disappointed. The food came out fast and filled our noses with the most delightful smells. It was beyond what we expected and I can easily say that their food is by far the best I've tasted in SF. Granted, this is based on ordering 4 dishes, but you can be damn sure I'll be back to try everything else on their menu moving forward. Server was super attentive with water and checking in on us. (Yay!)

But this review isn't just about the restaurant, food and service. While we waited for our food, a less fortunate man came in and was looking to dine. After listening to him talk, it was clear he was not sober; the service from the staff was heartwarming. After informing him they couldn't serve him, they sat and listened to him talk. About nothing and everything. My BF and I felt bad, so we asked the server to get him a soda and some food, and put it on our tab. The server went in the kitchen and came back with a box of chicken, rice and water. The gentleman thanked him and left. The server came over and thanked us for our generosity and said it was his duty to take care of the community they were in, but more importantly the patrons inside that supported them. Wow, human kindness DOES exist. I was touched. This made me appreciate the restaurant even more, and all happened before we got our food.

I salute the server, restaurant and what it stands for. Love does conquer all, so get your ass out to Lotus SF and enjoy their savory and perfectly spiced dishes!!!!

PS. You'll find a little surprise on the front of the menu re: Togo orders :) Happy eating!!!

You probably know already that the Mission is home to a number of appetizing Indian eateries that run the gamut from modern street cart to more traditional fare. Places like Deccan Spice (review: http://bit.ly/2IvTrj2), Ritu (formerly DUM) Indian Soul Food (review: http://bit.ly/2Mx1i1Z), and Aslam's Rasoi (review: http://bit.ly/2tAeImW) impress with their diverse executions and tasty results. I came here for a quiet lunch after perusing appliances at Cherin's nearby and honestly didn't think Lotus SF was quite in the memorable category.

They have all the expected dishes on their menu - curries, biriyani, naans, tandoori - and they offer lunch specials worthy of attention. I decided to go for the reasonably priced $11.95 Tandoori Chicken Lunch Special  because it was dark meat only, definitely my preference. It certainly came with a lot of extras which in heftier days would have been a plus but now just seemed more like a carbalooza. First came a basket of naan that was enough for a family of four, none of whom could afford to be anorexic (photo: http://bit.ly/2yMAXv9).

Then came the tandoori chicken leg and thigh, a medium-size portion though a bit over cooked as it lay sitting on a bed of sautéed white onions (photo: http://bit.ly/2tBGtLT). This came with a cup of dal (photo: http://bit.ly/2KqiRnf). But wait, there was more. On another plate were a salad, a big helping of basmati rice, and a huge samosa, very crusty from its bath in the fryer (photo: http://bit.ly/2N4hw3K). It was a lot of food, and if you're looking for by-the-numbers execution, this place was as good as any. But portion didn't rule out everything else for me as I felt mixed on the results.

FOOD - 3 stars...lots to eat at lunch but it was light on poultry and way heavy on carbs
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...the decor was quite nice in a traditional way
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...very quiet and efficient and a lot of guys on staff at once
TOTAL - 3 stars...middle-of-the-road Indian food in a 'hood with a whole lotta strong South Asian choices

You probably know already that the Mission is home to a number of appetizing Indian eateries that run the gamut from modern street cart to more traditional fare. Places like Deccan Spice (review: http://bit.ly/2IvTrj2), Ritu (formerly DUM) Indian Soul Food (review: http://bit.ly/2Mx1i1Z), and Aslam's Rasoi (review: http://bit.ly/2tAeImW) impress with their diverse executions and tasty results. I came here for a quiet lunch after perusing appliances at Cherin's nearby and honestly didn't think Lotus SF was quite in the memorable category.

They have all the expected dishes on their menu - curries, biriyani, naans, tandoori - and they offer lunch specials worthy of attention. I decided to go for the reasonably priced $11.95 Tandoori Chicken Lunch Special  because it was dark meat only, definitely my preference. It certainly came with a lot of extras which in heftier days would have been a plus but now just seemed more like a carbalooza. First came a basket of naan that was enough for a family of four, none of whom could afford to be anorexic (photo: http://bit.ly/2yMAXv9).

Then came the tandoori chicken leg and thigh, a medium-size portion though a bit over cooked as it lay sitting on a bed of sautéed white onions (photo: http://bit.ly/2tBGtLT). This came with a cup of dal (photo: http://bit.ly/2KqiRnf). But wait, there was more. On another plate were a salad, a big helping of basmati rice, and a huge samosa, very crusty from its bath in the fryer (photo: http://bit.ly/2N4hw3K). It was a lot of food, and if you're looking for by-the-numbers execution, this place was as good as any. But portion didn't rule out everything else for me as I felt mixed on the results.

FOOD - 3 stars...lots to eat at lunch but it was light on poultry and way heavy on carbs
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...the decor was quite nice in a traditional way
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...very quiet and efficient and a lot of guys on staff at once
TOTAL - 3 stars...middle-of-the-road Indian food in a 'hood with a whole lotta strong South Asian choices

My BF was feeling a bit under the weather and we just did a full week of going vegetarian, so I perused for the best "Vegetarian " near me. Indian popped up as a top cuisine so I thought a quick walk to the Naan & Curry on 3rd & King would work. Then, I came across Lotus SF. Lots of stars and rave reviews. 

Hopped in the car and headed towards the Mission at 8:30pm on a Thursday. Normally, parking is tough to find based on the time and day of week, but was plentiful and to our surprise. 

The exterior is clean with big windows showing you these beautiful upholstered chairs and tables ready for you inside. A white stone elephant greets you next to the front door, as does a smiling server upon entry. We were surprised, and for a quiet night, we chose a window seat and was equally thrilled at seeing the deliciousness inside their menu.

We chose garlic naan, basmati rice, palak paneer and a organic chicken coconut curry (extra $1.50 for organic chicken), a cup of mango lassi and Sonoma Zinfandel. We were NOT disappointed. The food came out fast and filled our noses with the most delightful smells. It was beyond what we expected and I can easily say that their food is by far the best I've tasted in SF. Granted, this is based on ordering 4 dishes, but you can be damn sure I'll be back to try everything else on their menu moving forward. Server was super attentive with water and checking in on us. (Yay!)

But this review isn't just about the restaurant, food and service. While we waited for our food, a less fortunate man came in and was looking to dine. After listening to him talk, it was clear he was not sober; the service from the staff was heartwarming. After informing him they couldn't serve him, they sat and listened to him talk. About nothing and everything. My BF and I felt bad, so we asked the server to get him a soda and some food, and put it on our tab. The server went in the kitchen and came back with a box of chicken, rice and water. The gentleman thanked him and left. The server came over and thanked us for our generosity and said it was his duty to take care of the community they were in, but more importantly the patrons inside that supported them. Wow, human kindness DOES exist. I was touched. This made me appreciate the restaurant even more, and all happened before we got our food.

I salute the server, restaurant and what it stands for. Love does conquer all, so get your ass out to Lotus SF and enjoy their savory and perfectly spiced dishes!!!!

PS. You'll find a little surprise on the front of the menu re: Togo orders :) Happy eating!!!

Greeting the customer with what looks like marble Ganeshas outside and big, brass ones inside, LOTUS SF continues with the theme of high quality and fine Indian art, from the fine paintings (including masterpieces of the Persian-influenced era) and a unique 3-D wood portrait (suggestive of the style of Yaacov Agam) of Indian Independence hero Kartar Singh Sarabha, to the fantastic floors (dramatic and sweeping marble-inlaid designs in bright blues, golds, and a variety of other colors and patterns--different for each section of the restaurant, and gorgeous faux-wood tile flooring in the bathrooms, which sparkle with cleanliness and chrome fixtures, and white-on-white, fine-geometric-patterned, fresco-like tile walls). 
And then there's lunch, all served on cloth tablecloths in beautiful, intricately patterned white-on-white china (made in Thailand) by charming staff from India and/or Nepal--while authentic Indian classical music plays in the background.
First time out, I had an extremely generous portion of the magnificent dal makhni (requesting 'medium spicy'), which came with sides of white basmati rice (every grain perfect) garnished with saffron and peas, a salad of field greens (if you want dressing, ask), a lovely, big, fat samosa (potato & peas), and a basket of exceptionally fresh, fragrant and tasty naan (they offer a variety of breads & flavors and gluten-free naan, too). I nearly broke out in Hallelujahs when I discovered that they did NOT sweeten their chai. I took home leftovers in the box they so graciously provided, as even I couldn't eat so much food in one sitting.
ALL THIS for $12 (plus a generous tip, which they so richly deserve)!
Of course, there were other vegetarian options at that price (next time, I'll try the chana masala) as well as meat dishes (chicken, lamb) and fish & seafood (for about $1 to $4 more). I did not explore desserts (but will try the gulab jamon). This is the real deal in Northern Indian cuisine and ambience. (I bet that was the owner I saw standing by.) I can hardly wait to go back for more!

fish tikka masala.review:
Wow just wow. This place was perfect.

My boyfriend and I arrived at this place 9ish. So the place was not busy whatsoever. When we arrived we were quickly greeted and sat down.

Food: I ordered the Chapati and Bengan Bharta. The Bengan bharta was not vegan so I asked the server if he could make it vegan and he said yes. When I got my food, I was extremely excited to try it because it looked so delicious! I first tried it with my chapati bread and it was so delicious. I definitely loved the spices with the eggplant. The flavor was so exceptional! I also tried it with brown rice and again amazed because it genuinely tasted that good to me. I'm definitely glad I ordered the Benga Bertha! 
My boyfriend ordered brown rice, fish tikka masala, and naan. He said his fish tikka masala was delicious. Overall, we really enjoyed our food. It was definitely a 5/5 for me!  

Service: From the beginning and end of our meal the service was spot on. Everyone was so helpful and kind. Especially when I asked for my dishes to be veganised. The servers were extremely spot on with the timing on asking us if we needed anything. It's such a small aspect but I really enjoy when they wait for all the food to be cooked and then serving it to us. Such a great experience with customer service!

The atmosphere of the place was quite relaxing! The decor and the look of the place was pleasing. Additionally, the whole restaurant is really clean!

I definitely recommend this place because the food is just very delicious, the place is clean, and the customer service is spot on. It's quite difficult to impress me but this place definitely did :)
